question: Given the two primary paradigms of AI in academic writing—semi-automatic assistance and full automation—how do the specific collaborative functionalities across the three phases of semi-automatic writing (preparation, writing, and revision) fundamentally contrast with the self-refining, multi-agent methodologies of full-automatic systems in terms of their reliance on human oversight, their current limitations in areas like citation and contextual accuracy, and their ultimate implications for the evolving habits and integrity of scholarly manuscript creation?
research_plan:
<research_outline>
  <section title="Introduction to AI in Academic Writing">
    <bullet_point>Define semi-automatic AI in academic writing, emphasizing human-in-the-loop.</bullet_point>
    <bullet_point>Define full-automatic AI in academic writing, emphasizing autonomous systems.</bullet_point>
    <bullet_point>Overview of the increasing role of AI in scholarly manuscript creation.</bullet_point>
  </section>
  <section title="Semi-Automatic AI: Collaborative Functionalities Across Writing Phases">
    <subsection title="Preparation Phase">
      <bullet_point>Literature Review Assistance: automated search, summary, and classification of relevant literature.</bullet_point>
      <bullet_point>Outline and Ideation Support: AI-assisted brainstorming and structuring of arguments.</bullet_point>
    </subsection>
    <subsection title="Writing Phase">
      <bullet_point>Content Generation: drafting of initial paragraphs, sentence rephrasing, and vocabulary suggestions.</bullet_point>
      <bullet_point>Grammar, Style, and Readability Enhancements: real-time feedback and correction.</bullet_point>
      <bullet_point>Citation Assistance: initial suggestion of citations, requiring human verification.</bullet_point>
    </subsection>
    <subsection title="Revision Phase">
      <bullet_point>Proofreading and Editing: identification of errors, inconsistencies, and areas for improvement.</bullet_point>
      <bullet_point>Feedback and Assessment: AI-driven feedback on clarity, coherence, and adherence to guidelines.</bullet_point>
      <bullet_point>Plagiarism Checking: identification of potential plagiarism for human review.</bullet_point>
    </subsection>
    <bullet_point>Overall emphasis on human oversight and critical faculty in decision-making.</bullet_point>
  </section>
  <section title="Full-Automatic AI: Self-Refining, Multi-Agent Methodologies">
    <bullet_point>Core Concepts: overview of self-refinement, iterative learning, and autonomous optimization.</bullet_point>
    <bullet_point>Multi-Agent Architectures: exploration of systems where multiple AI agents collaborate on writing tasks.</bullet_point>
    <bullet_point>Methodologies: examples of textual backpropagation, dynamic team selection, and automatic agent generation.</bullet_point>
    <bullet_point>Focus on end-to-end automation with minimal human intervention.</bullet_point>
  </section>
  <section title="Comparative Analysis: Semi-Automatic vs. Full-Automatic AI">
    <subsection title="Reliance on Human Oversight">
      <bullet_point>Semi-automatic: Human-in-the-loop, collaborative, AI as an assistant and enhancer.</bullet_point>
      <bullet_point>Full-automatic: Minimal to no human intervention, autonomous decision-making, AI as a primary author.</bullet_point>
      <bullet_point>Implications of different levels of oversight on accountability and control.</bullet_point>
    </subsection>
    <subsection title="Current Limitations">
      <bullet_point>Citation Accuracy: challenges for both, but more pronounced for full-automatic systems and implications for academic integrity.</bullet_point>
      <bullet_point>Contextual Accuracy and Nuance: difficulties in understanding deeper meaning and producing original insights, especially for full-automatic systems.</bullet_point>
      <bullet_point>Ethical Concerns: issues of authorship, bias, and responsible AI deployment.</bullet_point>
    </subsection>
    <subsection title="Implications for Scholarly Manuscript Creation">
      <bullet_point>Evolving Habits: changes in research workflows, time allocation, and skill sets for academics.</bullet_point>
      <bullet_point>Integrity of Scholarship: potential risks of widespread use of full-automatic systems (e.g., increased publication volume with decreased quality, self-plagiarism, misinformation).</bullet_point>
      <bullet_point>Future Outlook: the potential for hybrid models and advancements to address current limitations.</bullet_point>
    </subsection>
  </section>
  <section title="Conclusion">
    <bullet_point>Summary of the fundamental contrasts between the two paradigms.</bullet_point>
    <bullet_point>Outlook on the future of AI in academic writing and its transformative potential.</bullet_point>
    <bullet_point>Recommendations for ethical and responsible integration of AI in scholarly work.</bullet_point>
  </section>
</research_outline>
